headline: The Kraft Heinz Company Appoints Nicolas Amaya as President, North America
summary: PITTSBURGH & CHICAGO, February 18, 2026--The Kraft Heinz Company (NASDAQ: KHC) ("Kraft Heinz" or the "Company") today announced the appointment of Nicolas Amaya ("Nico") as President, North America, effective February 23, 2026. In this role, Amaya will lead the Company’s North America business, overseeing strategy, operations, and performance across Kraft Heinz’s largest market. Pedro Navio, current President, North America, will step down on February 22 to pursue other opportunities. Over his e

headline: Kraft Heinz replaces North American president with Kellanova exec
summary: Nicolas Amaya joins as new CEO Steve Cahillane taps a familiar face to return the ketchup and Lunchables maker to profitable growth.

headline: Marathon task at Kraft Heinz – can Steve Cahillane turn the tide?
summary: Cahillane steered Kellogg through a split but Kraft Heinz is a different ball game.

headline: High Dividend Packaged Foods: Relative Favorability
summary: The packaged foods industry has broadly declined over the last year with some producers dropping over 20%; dividend yields have expanded to as much as 9.5%.

headline: AI Anxiety Meets a Thrifty Consumer: Wall Street’s Post-Holiday Reality Check
summary: Wall Street returned from the long weekend with a mixed performance as investors weighed heavy concerns over AI-driven software valuations against a sobering outlook from the consumer staples sector.

headline: 5 Revealing Analyst Questions From Kraft Heinz’s Q4 Earnings Call
summary: Kraft Heinz’s fourth quarter results reflected ongoing challenges in packaged foods demand, as the company’s sales declined year over year in line with Wall Street expectations. Management attributed performance to sustained pressure on sales volumes, particularly in North America, and acknowledged underinvestment in its brand portfolio over the past decade. CEO Steve Cahillane was candid about the need for change, stating, “I knew that the company was underinvested… and indeed, I did find under
